results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to examine factors influencing reliable estimation of group bias and how to improve it. (e.g., 'In this paper, we examine two research questions...')
Sections 4 and 5 provide detailed descriptions of the simulation study and real-world data analysis, outlining the steps taken.
The document states the data was obtained from the UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository and provides a link: 'https://archive.ics.uci.edu/dataset/697/predict+students+dropout+and+academic+success'
Data is publicly available, so justification for non-sharing is not applicable.
The document describes the variables used and their origin, referencing previous work ([28]) and providing details about the dataset's characteristics (e.g., class distribution).

The document states the data was collected from students and mentions its original purpose: 'This dataset was collected to develop a machine learning model that predicts academic success and failure in higher education.'
The document does not mention whether the analysis code is publicly available.
Code is not shared, so justification is not applicable.
The document does not mention whether code for data preparation is shared.
Statistical tests (simulation, bootstrapping), models (logistic regression), and assumptions are described (e.g., equal error rate in simulation).
Effect sizes (e.g., FPR difference), confidence intervals (using Newcombe's method and bootstrapping), are reported and discussed.
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
The study is not qualitative, so data coding and analysis description is not applicable.
Results are presented with figures and clear descriptions of findings (e.g., impact of group size on variability).
Section 6.3 explicitly discusses limitations (e.g., mutually exclusive groups, limited metrics) and potential biases.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
